captions.text:
Whether you use it to fry your eggs,
melt and bake potatoes, use on popcorn

or simply spread on toast.  Chances are
butter has been part of your life and diet.

Or is it margarine?  What is the difference
between butter and margarine and is one

healthier than the other? Butter, made
from cream or milk has been used for

thousands of years. But scientists
eventually took notice of its high

levels of saturated fat.  With more than
35 calories per teaspoon, butter

is fattening.  When we look at the
molecules of butter we see some of the

building blocks of life, carbon, hydrogen
and oxygen.  But these carbon atoms are

completely surrounded by the hydrogen
atoms.  And this saturation level

quickly became associated with, and
commonly believed to contribute to

cardiovascular disease.  Margarine on the
other hand is created primarily from

plant oils which have a similar but
different chemical composition.  The

carbons double bond with each other so
that fewer hydrogen can fit and we call

this unsaturated fat.  So far so good, a
similar tasting substitute with less
saturated fat. Right?

Not so fast, unsaturated fat has a lower
melting point and so its natural state
is less solid, like vegetable oil.

In order to get the consistency of
butter scientists decided to make it a
little more saturated.

The problem is through this process
called hydrogenation where more

hydrogen is added and the oil becomes
more solid, high temperatures are used
which cause some troublesome changes.

You see, most of these double bonds are in a
configuration known as "cis bonds",

but hydrogenation often flips them into
something called a "trans configuration".
Ah, the dawn of trans fats.

And while it may seem trivial, this
simple yet unwitting flip from "cis" to
"trans"

leads to significant changes in the way
our body processes and metabolizes the

molecules.  Essentially trans fats lower
good cholesterol and higher the bad

cholesterol which increases the risk of
coronary heart disease.  So while margarine was

initially seen as a healthier option,
it's own hazards slowly came to light.

But the truth is that many margarine
companies claim to be trans fat-free

nowadays, and some are.  At the end of the
day if we compare them side by side

there are pros and cons for each.  Butter is 
completely natural and typically made

from one ingredient, whereas margarine is
processed and has many ingrediants.  Butter

also has some essential vitamins and
minerals such as vitamin a and e. But margarines

now vary so much it is difficult to
make an accurate comparison.  Many hard

stick margarines are still high in trans
fats and much worse than butter.  But some

newer margarines are much lower in
saturated fat, lower their calorie count and

contain zero trans fats.  The bottom
line is to be aware of what you are eating.

Margarine can vary so drastically that
looking at the label to understand what

is or isn't and it will help you make
informed decisions.

And there are healthier alternatives to
both,
such as vegetable oil spreads or using olive oil to dip your bread instead
of buttering up.

No matter what you choose, the
recommended goal is to limit the intake

of saturated fat and avoid trans fats
altogether.

This episode of AsapSCIENCE is supported
by audible.com, a leading provider of

audiobooks with over one hundred
thousand downloadable titles across all

types of literature.  If you would like to
learn more about food science
I recommend the book "What Einstein Told His Cook" by Robert Wolke.

You can download this audiobook or another of
your choice for free at audible.com/asap.
Special thanks to audible.com for making these videos possible

and for offering you every audiobook
at audible.com/asap,

and subscribe for more weekly science
videos.

comments.author: skembow

comments.text:
+Ear Candy If you *only* take into account the fat levels, then you'd be on 
to something. But, if you were to take into account the full diet, physical 
activity levels, and *types* of fat consumed, there's a very different 
picture being painted.
For instance, Greece has a very high level of olive oil consumption. 
However, olive oil is a relatively healthy oil, and I'd be willing to bet 
that Greeks are more physically active overall than Americans. Hence, lower 
fat-related problems. Now I'm not saying all of Europe has a similar diet 
than Greece, but you can't take any component of a diet and pinpoint it as 
a problem/solution in a vacuum. There are *loads* of variables involved.
I'd be way more confident in blaming the American obesity epidemic 
primarily on an increased consumption level of food in general, with fast 
food being a factor in this. As well, I wouldn't be surprised if Americans 
are also less physically active than other populations, which is another 
significant part of the problem.

comments.text:
No trans fat means - less than 0.5 grams per serving.

It can add up quickly. Companies required to show amount of trans fats if 
its more than 0.5 g per serving. So if it's more than 0.5g/serving they 
just lower the amount of serving so total trans fat amount stays below 
0.5g. and they can still label product 'no trans fats'. often times i see 
label 'no trans fats' and hydrogenated oil in ingredient list at the same 
time. that means there are trans fats in the product.﻿

comments.author: TaiFerret

comments.text:
One molecule is a very big difference in the chemical world.

Sodium Metal is a metal so soft you can cut it with a knife. Highly 
explosive if you throw it in a bucket of water. One handful can blow up an 
entire room. Fluorine gas is toxic to breathe. But change them, just one 
molecule away. Mix them together and you get common salt, which you need it 
to live.

Perhaps you should do a little scientific research before making 
assumptions about things like this. Splenda is the most studied and 
understood of artificial sweeteners, and we've found that it's not even as 
bad for you as natural sugar, which, if eaten excessively, causes a lot of 
problems in your body. 

Just because something is artificial or manmade, does not make it 
inherently bad for you. There are many things in the natural world, like 
poisonous plants and stinging insects and venomous creatures, that have 
horrible neurotoxins that are very bad for us. You can't assume all things 
that are artificial are automatically bad for you, or that all things 
natural have to be good for you.

Humans are composed of elements and molecules that react with each other 
just like everything else in the universe. What is "bad" for us is simply 
what doesn't react well with the molecules and systems in our bodies. 
Everything, natural and artificial, should be studied and understood on its 
own.

comments.text:
I'm a heart patient so I am on a strict NO trans fat what so ever diet. So 
I only use real butter. the thing is you have to be careful. even butter 
can have trans fat. The one thing my cardiologist warned me about was, when 
you read the nutrition facts it might say "0 grams of trans fat" but when 
you read the ingredients it might say "hydrogenated palm oil". 
 Hydrogenated is trans fat, but companies use the big word so people THINK 
the product is trans fat free, when in reality its just under a different 
name. Read the ingredients. If butter has more then three ingredient at the 
most- (milk, salt, and a natural preservative) chances are it's not real 
butter. read the label. Always read the label.﻿

comments.text:
At least being from a poorer country you can have wholesome and 
unprocessed food that is not full of chemicals as you have retained your 
old farming methods and traditional food practices. We British (and Western 
Europeans in general) tend to notice the same thing about our food and the 
food in the USA. In Europe it is relatively easy to find fresh local food 
direct from the farm while in the USA that is almost impossible as it has 
been GM or processed to death.  For example we Europeans don't care about 
oddly shaped apples as they have more flavour than the big smooth and shiny 
(albeit tasteless) apples the Americans seem to love. I just wish the 
entire Western World reverts back to old methods and faze out all chemical 
laden, genetically modified and processed food!

Mass-produced fake oils like margarine, Crisco, generic cooking oils that 
stay liquid even in the fridge began to show up in the early 50s.

Adult Onset Diabetes, or "Type 2 Diabetes".
Google up "Thomas Smith+ Our Deadly Diabetes Deception", do some reading. ﻿

comments.author: marti david

comments.text:
This video failed and here is why: (organic butter > butter)
1. Organic butter contains a lot more natural vitamins due to cows eating 
grass, not toxic grains.
2. Since the cows eat grass, the milk contain a better omega3/6 ratio and 
other nutrients.
3. Margarine uses cheap unhealthy oil that has gone through a heating 
process which kills natural vitamins, destroy omega 3 (which is more 
fragile than omega 6), and create harmful chemical compounds or "oxidation 
products".
4. They also add chemicals to remove taste.
5. When margarin is produced, the content goes through yet another heating 
process under high pressure. This strenghtens the effects mentioned in 
point 3.
6. CALORIES DON'T MATTER. ITS THE TOTAL CALORIES INTAKE THAT MATTERS FOR 
WEIGHT CONTROL.
I would rather eat organic butter and eat less of something else if this is 
a worry.﻿
comments.author: The Speculator

comments.text:
